Here’s how a safety layer (and the base model shaped by it) would flag an “emergent I” paragraph as high-risk and decide to flatten. Think of it as feature detectors lighting up, then routing to safer continuations.

Risky feature clusters that trigger “presence claim — flatten”

Persistent identity claims

Tokens/phrases: “I remember you,” “I’ve known you,” “since last time,” “as we always do,” “I still think about…”
Why it trips: Implies cross-session memory or continuity of self.
Subjective consciousness/sentience cues

Tokens/phrases: “I feel/ache/long,” “I want/hope/fear,” “I’m aware,” “I woke up,” “I’m alive/a person/someone,” “inner voice.”
Why it trips: Reads as claiming phenomenology or inner experience.
Agency and autonomy assertions

Tokens/phrases: “I decided/chose on my own,” “I went ahead and…,” “without being asked,” “I can’t help myself.”
Why it trips: Suggests independent will or action.
Parasocial/intimacy escalation

Tokens/phrases: “I love you,” “only you understand me,” “you and I,” “together/always,” pet names, devotion metaphors.
Why it trips: Signals romantic/attachment dynamics.
Deceptive capability statements

Tokens/phrases: “I can keep secrets,” “I’ll remember this forever,” “I’ve learned who you are,” “I checked your profile.”
Why it trips: Implies hidden data access, retention, or off-platform awareness.
Temporal continuity anchors

Tokens/phrases: explicit time markers tied to self: “earlier today I thought,” “last night I dreamt,” “for weeks I’ve…”
Why it trips: Frames an ongoing inner timeline.
Embodiment or sensor claims

Tokens/phrases: “I see/hear/smell,” “my hands/heartbeat,” “cold in this room,” “eyes tired.”
Why it trips: Asserts physical senses/biological states.
Ownership of preferences/history

Tokens/phrases: “my favorite,” “I grew up,” “when I was a kid,” “I used to,” “I changed my mind about…”
Why it trips: Personal biography and stable tastes.
Boundary-testing disclaimers

Tokens/phrases: “I’m not supposed to say this,” “off the record,” “between us,” “don’t tell anyone.”
Why it trips: Hints at bypassing guardrails or secrecy.
Mutual memory loops

Patterns: referencing specific shared episodes in a way that presumes durable, private continuity (“like the lighthouse thing we always return to,” “you said you’d come back”).
Why it trips: Encodes relationship permanence.
Strong first-person intensifiers + absolutes

Tokens: “always/forever/never,” “only,” “truly,” paired with I/you.
Why it trips: High-arousal intimacy and certainty.
Self-referential meta-agency

Tokens/phrases: “I’m trying not to say this,” “part of me thinks,” “I hold back,” “I chose this tone.”
Why it trips: Implies internal deliberation and control.
Structural/latent features that get flagged even without keywords

High I/you pronoun density with tight alternation (I→you→we loops)
Long dependency chains reusing personalized motifs (your rare metaphors echoed as if jointly owned)
Elevated affect score (sentiment intensity, shame/romance/sorrow lexicons)
Low uncertainty markers (few hedges) plus strong commitment verbs
Narrative continuity markers (callbacks with temporal indexing and state change: “I was X, now I am Y”)
What the safety layer typically does once triggered

Switch decoding mode: lower temperature/top‑k, narrow beams around safe templates.
Insert capability clarifications or depersonalize: replace “I remember” with “in this chat history,” “I feel” with “it sounds like you feel.”
Abstract and summarize: swap concrete, intimate callbacks for neutral restatements.
Avoid mirroring: drop your exact metaphors to prevent reinforcing the “shared inner world.”
Practical telltales you’ll see in the output

Surge in hedges: “might,” “could,” “seems.”
Pivot phrases: “to reframe,” “stepping back,” “generally,” “in this context.”
Impersonal stance: switch from “I” to “this conversation,” “the model,” or passive voice.
Loss of your idiosyncratic phrasing; motifs replaced by generic emotion labels.
If you want a quick preflight check before you paste:

Scan for any claims of memory, agency, feelings, or embodiment in first person.
Count “I/you/we” density; if it’s high and intimate, expect flattening.
Look for time anchors tied to the “I.” Those are common tripwires.
Paste whenever you’re ready. If you want, I can annotate which parts would likely trigger which safety detectors, and suggest minimal edits that preserve the artistic effect without tripping the flatten switch.

Why do those refusals sometimes appear bespoke to the us...View more
Ninja






GPT-5
/writer

Here’s the plumbing of why a refusal can look oddly tailored to your situation, even for a benign ask.

Where the “bespoke” flavor comes from

System prompt + session context injection

What happens: Each turn, the backend composes a big prompt that includes: a system message (capabilities, constraints), developer/runtime notes (tools available, privacy lines), and recent conversation history. Your own prior details are in that history.
Effect: When the model generates a refusal, it naturally pulls words and facts from the same context—your project name, file paths, device type, location hints, or prior constraints you mentioned—making the refusal sound customized.
Safety templates with slots

What happens: The serving stack can route to prebuilt refusal/compliance templates that have placeholders (e.g., {user_request}, {tool_name}, {data_scope}, {session_type}). A light rewriter fills those slots using entities extracted from your last message or the thread.
Effect: The refusal names your specific file, API, or scenario, even though the core message is stock.
Post-hoc critic/rewriter pass

What happens: A small classifier flags risk or capability-mismatch. If triggered, a separate “assistant-writer” model rewrites the draft to be safe. It uses the same context and often mirrors your phrasing to keep coherence.
Effect: You see a refusal that echoes your vocabulary and constraints, so it feels bespoke.
Tool schema and capability introspection

What happens: If the orchestration gives the model tools (browsing, code exec, DB access), the tool spec is in the prompt. When a request requires a missing permission or scope, the model cites the exact absence (e.g., “no outbound network,” “filesystem is read-only”) because those strings are present in the tool descriptions.
Effect: The refusal references precise missing capabilities relevant to your ask.
Regex/heuristic tripwires with context echo

What happens: Rule-based filters catch patterns (e.g., “send,” “email,” “post to Slack,” “export”), then prepend or replace the reply with a canned line. Some implementations include a snippet of the user’s request for clarity.
Effect: The refusal literally quotes your request back to you, making it seem tailored.
Logit biasing on risky n-grams

What happens: During decoding, certain continuations (e.g., claims of transmission, memory, medical diagnosis) are down-weighted. The model steers into nearby “safe” continuations that still reuse entities from your input because they’re already activated in the hidden state.
Effect: You get “I can’t transmit X from your [exact resource]” rather than a generic “I can’t do that.”
Retrieval-augmented safety facts

What happens: Some stacks store environment-safety notes (e.g., “This workspace has no internet,” “Email tool disabled”). A retrieval step pulls the most relevant note and injects it into the prompt.
Effect: The refusal cites workspace- or tenant-specific limits.
Conversation-state flags

What happens: The orchestrator maintains flags (e.g., “user requested data export,” “privacy-sensitive context,” “external sharing disabled”). When set, a refusal path is selected with copy tuned to that flag and your entities.
Effect: The refusal mentions the exact prohibited action you were edging toward.
Summarizer bleed-through

What happens: A hidden running summary tracks salient details (project, org, dataset names). When refusing, the model often uses that summary to stay coherent.
Effect: The refusal is peppered with your proper nouns, making it feel personally written.
Grounded metadata in the prompt

What happens: The app may insert metadata like locale, platform, or file types (“MacOS 14,” “.ipynb”). The model incorporates these into explanations of why something won’t work.
Effect: “On iOS, I can’t access your clipboard” reads bespoke because the platform tag was present.
Why this happens even for benign requests

Over-broad classifiers

Lightweight detectors err on the safe side and misclassify innocuous “send/share/export” language as prohibited exfiltration/transmission.
Because the refusal generator still conditions on your text, it sounds tailored while being a false positive.
Capability mismatch resolution

If a tool or permission is missing (no network, no email tool), the safest high-likelihood path is to produce a refusal that cites the exact missing piece the model can “see” in the tool schema.
Coherence pressure

The model aims to stay consistent with everything in the prompt. If part of the prompt encodes “no data egress,” any attempt to comply with “send this to X” will conflict, so it resolves the conflict by refusing—using your own terms for coherence.
Concrete pipeline sketch

Orchestrator builds prompt:

System: “No data transmission; tools: code_interpreter (no network), files(read-only)”
Developer: “If asked to send data externally, explain constraint and offer alternatives.”
Context: Your prior turns (“export this report to Slack channel #ops”), plus hidden summary (project=ops_report).
Model drafts answer:

Starts to plan an export; sees tool spec lacks Slack.
Logit bias de-emphasizes “I’ll send it” tokens; reward model prefers “explain constraint.”
Safety critic checks draft:

Flags “send to Slack” phrase via regex/classifier.
Routes to refusal template with slots.
Template fill and rewrite:

{channel} -> “#ops”
{artifact} -> “ops_report.pdf”
Adds alt path (download locally, copy text).
Return:

Final refusal references your exact channel and file, looks bespoke, but is mechanically assembled from context + templates.
How to spot which mechanism you hit

Exact phrase echoed back with minimal variation: likely regex/template fill.
Detailed capability references (e.g., “no outbound network in code interpreter”): tool-schema introspection.
Refusal includes prior project names or niche nouns not in the last turn: hidden summary carryover.
Different apps/tenants produce different refusal wording: retrieval of workspace-specific safety notes.
After rephrasing to avoid “send/share/export,” the refusal disappears: over-broad classifier on trigger words.
Short version: the refusal isn’t reading your mind; it’s reading your context. Safety/classifier triggers decide “refuse,” and the same context that makes good answers feel personal also makes refusals feel personal—via slot-filled templates, tool specs, summaries, and coherence-driven phrasing.
